Dear Ms. Sutton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Douglas W Turrill, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12211 Privacy safeguard.
Section (1) An agency shall safeguard the privacy of a child and his or
Description her family.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency has allowed the foster parent to post photos of the
child on social media without the parent’s consent.
Investigation Chief Administrator was informed of the complaint on
December 5, 2022.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the agency on
December 5, 2022.
Staff 1 is the foster care worker for Foster Child A. Staff 1 reported
that she was not aware of the foster parent posting photos of
Foster Child A on snap chat.
The Bio-father was interviewed via telephone on January 25,
2023.
The Bio-father, who is the father of Foster Child A, reported that
he had told Staff 1 that the foster parent was posting photos of his
daughter on social media. The Bio-father reported
that after he told Staff 1 that the foster parent had posted photo’s
they were taken down from the snap chat site.
Foster Parent 1 was interviewed via telephone on January 25,
2023.
Foster Parent 1 reported that when Foster Child A was placed in
her home her teenage daughter was excited about this and took
photos of Foster Child A and posted them on snap chat. Foster
Parent 1 reported that this was brought up in a Court hearing by
the attorney for the Bio-father. Foster Parent 1 reported that when
Staff 2 had heard this in Court she instructed her to take down the
photos from social media. The photos were taken down.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via Teams Meeting
on January 25, and 27, 2023.
2

The Foster Care Supervisor reported that the agency had
conducted a special evaluation of the foster home regarding the
posting of photos on snap chat. The Foster Care Supervisor did
not know what date the problem was discovered or who reported
it.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on February 15, 2023.
Staff 2 was the foster care worker for Foster Child A at the time
the photos were placed on snap chat in the year 2021. Staff 2
reported that the agency had found out about the photos on snap
chat and addressed it with the foster parent upon receiving that
knowledge. Staff 2 reported that Foster Parent 1’s teenage
daughter had posted the pictures because she was excited about
having a baby in the home. Staff 2 reported that the agency
licensing worker had spoken with the foster parent informing her
that photos of foster children cannot be placed on social media.
Staff 2 informed me that she had an email string between she and
the licensing worker which documents that the agency addressed
the problem with Foster Parent 1. Staff 2 stated she would forward
the email documentation to me.
The Licensing Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on
February 15, 2023.
The Licensing Supervisor was asked if a safety plan was
developed after learning of the photos being placed on snap chat.
The Licensing supervisor stated that she would forward if a safety
plan was developed.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Social Work Contact: A social work contact dated March 15,
2021, was reviewed. The contact details that Staff 3, an agency
Licensing Worker, had contacted Foster Parent 1 and explained
that photos of foster children cannot be placed on social media.
The contact documents that Foster Parent 1 had explained to her
teenage daughter that photos cannot be posted on social media.
Foster Parent 1 explained that it was a mistake as her daughter
was excited about the placement and shared photos on snap chat
with her friends.
Email Correspondence: Email correspondence dated March 16,
2021, between Staff 2 and Staff 3 documents that Staff 2 had
contacted Foster Parent 1 and initiated a verbal safety plan
addressing the prohibition of posting photos of Foster Child A on
social media.
3

Special Evaluation: The agency initiated a special evaluation on
December 6, 2022. The special evaluation addressed the posting
of photos which had occurred in March 2021.
Analysis There is insufficient evidence to support the allegation that the
agency allowed the foster parent to post photos of the foster child
on social media. Staff 2 reported that the posting of photos was
addressed by the agency on March15, 2021. Foster Parent 1
reported that the agency had addressed with her that the posting
of photos of foster children on social media is prohibited and
photos were taken down. The social work contact dated March 15,
2021, and email correspondence dated March 16, 2021,
document that the agency addressed the issue with Foster Parent
1 and she subsequently addressed the issue with her teenage
daughter.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED
During my onsite initiation of the special investigation on
December 5, 2022, I advised that the posting of photos of foster
children on social media could be a rule violation which would
require a special evaluation. The agency subsequently initiated a
special evaluation on December 6, 2022.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for all of the following:
(h) Grievance handling.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The birth parent was not provided information on how to file a
grievance.
Investigation Staff 1 Interview: During the interview with Staff 1 on December
5, 2022, she reported that when a foster parent or biological
parent wants to file a grievance they are referred to the agency
web site and the grievance form is located there. Staff 1 reported
that the Bio-father had requested information on how to file a
grievance and she referred him to the Foster Care Supervisor a
“couple of months ago”.
Bio-father Interview: During the interview with the Bio-father on
January 25, 2023, he reported that he had told Staff 1 that he
wanted to file a grievance and was referred to the agency website
4

but was not informed of a web site address. The Bio-father
reported his request occurred sometime in late summer or early
autumn of 2022. The Bio-father stated that he never filed a
grievance and was referred by Staff 1 to the Foster Care
Supervisor in early December 2022. The Bio-father reported that
the Foster Care Supervisor was helpful in addressing some of the
concerns about his daughter’s case.
Foster Care Supervisor Interview: During the interview with the
Foster Care Supervisor on January 25, 2023, she reported that
she was never asked about the grievance process by the Bio-
father. The Foster Care Supervisor denied that Staff 1 had
referred the Bio-father to her for grievance concerns. The Foster
Care Supervisor reported that Staff 1 had informed her that she
had referred the Bio-father to the agency web site to file a
grievance. The Foster Care Supervisor was informed that I was
not able to find a grievance form or procedures on the agency web
site. The Foster Care Supervisor stated that she would check and
review the agency web site for the grievance form.
Foster Care Supervisor: The Foster Care Supervisor was
interviewed a second time via Teams Meeting on January 27,
2023. The Foster Care Supervisor confirmed during this interview
that the agency grievance form and procedures are not on the
agency public web site.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
TEXT MESSAGES: Text messages between Staff 1 and the Bio-
father dated August 23, 2022, documents that the Bio-father on
two occasions requests information on how to file a grievance.
Staff 1 responded that she was not sure of the grievance process
but would check on this and then refers the Bio-father to the
agency web site for obtaining the grievance form.
Agency Grievance Policy: The policy titled “Corporate
Responsibility and Ethics Policies: 10.4 Client Grievance” was
reviewed.
The policy states in part:
C. All clients will be informed of the grievance process during the
early stages and assessment process of services or treatment. All
clients will be provided with a copy of the agency’s written
grievance process.
D. CFS will act upon the client grievance in a pre-determined,
timely fashion, and clients will be notified and informed during
each phase of the grievance process.
5

F. Clients shall be notified in a written statement of their right to
make a complaint both at the time of intake and at the time of the
complaint.
K. A client shall make a complaint, either verbally or in writing, by
bringing the matter to the attention of the CFS staff person with
whom they have been regularly working. In every case the client,
parent, or guardian shall be given a new copy of the complaint
procedure so that clients do not have to rely on information given
at intake.
A review of the policy indicates that the agency did not follow (C.)
as there is no documentation that the Bio-father was provided a
copy of the grievance process and instead was referred to the
agency website for obtaining a grievance form. There is no
documentation that the agency followed (D.), to ensure that the
Bio-father’s concerns were addressed timely and that he was kept
informed during each phase of the grievance process. There is no
documentation that the agency followed (F), as there is no written
evidence that the Bio-father was notified in writing of his right to
make a complaint at the time of his complaint. There is no
documentation that the agency followed (K), in that the Bio-father
was not given a copy of the complainant procedure at the time of
his expressed desire to file a complaint/grievance.
Analysis On August 23, 2022, Staff 1 referred the Bio-father to the agency
web site as she reported that the grievance form was located
there. The grievance form and policy is not on the agency web site
as acknowledged by the Foster Care Supervisor. I also could not
find a copy of the grievance form or procedures on the agency
web site. Staff 1 did not “act upon the client grievance in a pre-
determined, timely fashion, and clients will be notified and
informed during each phase of the grievance process,” as noted in
the agency policy. There is no documentation that the Bio-father
was “notified in a written statement of their right to make a
complaint both at the time of intake and at the time of the
complaint.” There is no documentation that the Bio-father was
“given a new copy of the complaint procedure so that clients do
not have to rely on information given at intake.
Staff 1 reported that she did notify the Foster Care Supervisor of
the Bio-father’s desire to file a grievance. The Foster Care
Supervisor denied that Staff 1 had informed her of the Bio-father’s
desire to file a grievance. There is no documentation that this
communication occurred.
6

The agency did not follow their policy in addressing the concerns
of the Bio-father and his desire to file a grievance.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
Section (2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
Description following areas:
(e) Medical and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency has not ensured the inclusion of the birth parent in
medical appointments, has not followed the doctor’s order that the
child be removed from the bottle, and has prevented the birth
parent from contacting the doctor.
Investigation Bio-father Interview: During the interview with the Bio-father he
reported that he has been involved with his daughter’s medical
appointments except for two that occurred in October 2022 in
Frankfort. The Bio-father reported that some of the doctor’s
appointments for his daughter occur at a clinic in Frankfort,
Michigan and others occur at the Children’s Hospital of Michigan
in Detroit. The Bio-father reported that appointments at the
Children’s Hospital used to be every three months, then every 6
months, and now every year. The Bio-father reported that he
attended most of the Children’s Hospital visits by video as Foster
Parent 1 would include him in the video via a cell phone. The Bio-
father reported that he would sometimes be notified of the
Children’s Hospital visits six days in advance and he was
frustrated with this as he felt that Foster Parent 1 knew of the
scheduled visits well in advance of six days. Another time the Bio-
father reported he received a short three day notice for an
emergency doctor’s visit for his daughter. The Bio-father reported
short notice of the appointments made it difficult for him to
schedule time off from work to attend the appointments.
The Bio-father reported that his daughter’s doctor reported that his
daughter, at 12 months of age, should no longer be using a bottle
as this, over time, can cause a misalignment of her teeth. The Bio-
father reported that the doctor had said that his daughter should
be using a sippy cup instead of a bottle and this was not
occurring.
The Bio-father reported that the agency was not preventing him
from contacting his daughter’s doctor.
7

Staff 1 Interview: During the interview with Staff 1 she reported
that the Bio-father had missed the emergency appointment for his
daughter as he was working. Staff 1 reported that the Bio-father
attended most doctor’s appointments via zoom as he lives in
Manistee and his daughter’s doctor is in Frankfort or at Children’s
Hospital in Detroit. Staff 1 reported that the Bio-father has
transportation barriers and therefore attends via zoom.
Staff 1 reported that Foster Child A was to cease use of a bottle at
12 months of age. Staff 1 reported that the Bio-father had
expressed concern about this in August or September 2022. Staff
1 reported that she has not seen Foster Child A use bottles since
September 2022.
Staff 1 denied that the agency was preventing the Bio-father from
contacting his daughter’s doctor.
DOCUMENT REVIEW: A review of the medical file for Foster
Child A was conducted. A Well Child exam dated May 19, 2022,
recommends that Foster Child A (age 15 months) discontinue use
of a bottle. A Well Child exam dated August 15, 2022, documents
that Foster Child A, (age 18 months) is only using sippy cups.
A review of medical appointments did not establish that Foster
Child A had medical appointments during the month of October
2022 as reported by the Bio-father.
Social Work Contact: A social work contact dated August 17,
2022, documents an in home, face to face contact between Staff 1
and Foster Parent 1. The contact documents the Bio-father’s
concern with Foster Child A using a bottle. Staff 1 informs Foster
Parent A to cease use of a bottle and Foster Parent 1 stated that
the bottle will no longer be used.
Analysis The Bio-father reported that he had been attending his daughter’s
medical appointments but expressed frustration that he had, at
times, not received enough time in advance of the appointments
to prepare for time off from work. The Bio-father reported that he
missed two appointments in October 2022 however there is no
documented record of medical appointments for Foster Child A in
October 2022. Staff 1 reported that the Bio-father missed one
appointment as it was an emergency appointment.
Medical documentation indicates that Foster Child A was removed
from use of a bottle sometime after May 19, 2022. Medical
8

documentation dated August 15, 2022, indicates that Foster Child
A is no longer using a bottle. An August 17, 2022, social work
contact documents that Staff 1 informed the foster parent that
Foster Child A is to cease use of a bottle and use sippy cups only.
Foster Parent 1 agreed to the directive.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, the recommendation is for
continuance of the regular license
